title: Brexit survey revealed: What you would do if given second shot at EU referendum
text:

Thousands of Brexiteers have revealed that if there were to be a re-run of the EU referendum they would vote in. 
A national poll of more than 40,000 people showed one in seven people who voted leave in the June 23 referendum would now vote in, compared to one in 11 of remain voters who would now back ‘leave’. 
In the North East, 11.9% of readers who responded to our survey said they would change their vote to ‘remain’ if they were asked again, while 8% of remainers would now leave. 
However the results of what is believed to be the biggest post-Brexit poll - by our publishers Trinity Mirror - would still mean that the region as a whole voted to quit Europe. 
A quarter of those who responded also said that they felt less positive about the future on the back of Theresa May’s 12-point Brexit plan. 
The plan came after months of pressure on the Prime Minister to spell out her red lines as Britain leaves the EU. 
Mrs May said there would be a “clean break” with the EU, including leaving the lucrative single market. 
She said Britain would seek a new partnership, “not partial membership, associate membership or anything that leaves us half-in, half-out.” 
And she threatened to walk if the terms aren’t good enough, declaring: “No deal for Britain is better than a bad deal for Britain.” Prime Minister Theresa May (Photo: Niall Carson/PA Wire) 
In the negotiations, North East readers said that Mrs May should focus on immigration control - with 55% of our survey respondents urging her to prioritise borders over markets. 
Since the referendum result and Mrs May’s revelations that she would be taking the UK out of the single market, Scotland’s First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has given strong indications that there will be a second independence referendum. 
Speaking in Holyrood recently, she said: “It is becoming clearer by the day that Scotland’s voice is simply not being heard or listened to within the UK. 
“The claims about Scotland being an equal partner are being exposed as nothing more than empty rhetoric.” 
More than half of the 2,536 North East readers who took part in our survey felt that it was now more likely that the UK would break up. 
The position of the Liberal Democrats that there should be a second referendum once the terms of the deal are know was given support by 46%. 
Lib Dem leader Tim Farron said that it would be a “theft of democracy” if there was not a second referendum. 
He said: “They seem happy to start with democracy and end in a stitch-up. 
“The Liberal Democrats are clear - we demand a vote of the people on the final deal and without that we will not vote for Article 50 called for the public to be given a second referendum on the terms of the final EU-UK deal.” Read More 
The North East resoundingly returned a Brexit vote last year with 778,103 voting out and 562,595 voting in. 
Every North East authority beside Newcastle - which only marginally voted remain - bolted for the exit door. 
The exit led many to fear for the future of jobs and growth in the region with more than £400m in European aid set to be axed. 
Funding arrangements are yet to be agreed however as the Government is still yet to trigger Article 50 which starts the process of withdrawing from the EU. 
A bill to confer power on the Prime Minister to trigger Article 50 is soon to go through the House of Lords and if passed in good time Mrs May hopes to start the process of leaving by April. Read More
